title: Jack Elliott - Jack Takes The Floor (1958)
description:
In the engine of modern music, this is one of the spark plugs. Jack Elliott Takes The Floor (later released as Muleskinner) was recorded off the cuff at London\&#039;s Topic Records. Jack talks us into each song with wry, leisurely intros that are worth the price of admission alone. His guitar technique was an education to the hard-stumming \"folk singers\" of the time, but also impacted on later popular music.
  The album pulls together a pantheon of previously little-known source - including Jesse Fuller, Reverend Gary David, field holler, and prison blues - and is remarkably hard edged. The raw, unadorned beauty of \"Dinky\&#039;s Song\" och \"Black Baby\" remain spine-chilling highlights. \"Mule Skinner\&#039;s Blues\" and \"San Francisco Bay Blues\" bacame hallmarks of Elliott\&#039;s work.
  Jack played frequently with Woodie Guthrie in tie 1950s. Having settled in New York in 1961, he met a kid in Guthrie\&#039;s hospital room who was soon to have a poster annoucning his own first NYC gig: \"Son of Jack Elliott - Bob Dylan\". In chronicles, Dylan desribes first hearing ... Takes the floor: \"I felt like I\&#039;d been into sudden hell ... His voice leaps all over the room ... and he plays the guitar effortlessy in a fluid flat-picking perfect style...\"
  Paul McCartney, Mick Jagger, and Keith Richards have all also acknowledged Jack\&#039;s influence. Little wonder: this release is still as engaging as it was in 1958.
(Src: SJar, 1001 Albums you must hear before you die)
